medical: PREOPERATIVE DIAGNOSIS: History of polyps. POSTOPERATIVE DIAGNOSES: 1. Normal colonoscopy, left colonic diverticular disease. 2. 3+ benign prostatic hypertrophy. PROCEDURE PERFORMED: Total colonoscopy and photography. GROSS FINDINGS: This is a 74-year-old white male here for recheck colonoscopy for a history of polyps. After signed informed consent, blood pressure monitoring, EKG monitoring, and pulse oximetry monitoring, he was brought to the Endoscopic Suite. He was given 100 mg of Demerol, 3 mg of Versed IV push slowly. Digital examination revealed a large prostate for which he is following up with his urologist. No nodules. 3+ BPH. Anorectal canal was within normal limits. No stricture tumor or ulcer. The Olympus CF 20L video endoscope was inserted per anus. The anorectal canal was visualized, was normal. The sigmoid, descending, splenic, and transverse showed scattered diverticula. The hepatic, ascending, cecum, and ileocecal valve was visualized and was normal. The colonoscope was removed. The air was aspirated. The patient was discharged with high-fiber, diverticular diet. Recheck colonoscopy three years.
layman:
PREOPERATIVE DIAGNOSIS: The patient had polyps before.  
POSTOPERATIVE DIAGNOSES:  
1. The colonoscopy was normal, but the left side of the colon had diverticular disease (small pouches).  
2. The patient has moderate benign enlargement of the prostate (3+ BPH).  

PROCEDURE PERFORMED: A full colonoscopy with pictures was done.  

GROSS FINDINGS:  
The patient is a 74‑year‑old white man who came back for a follow‑up colonoscopy because he had polyps before. After he signed the consent form, his blood pressure, heart rhythm, and oxygen levels were monitored. He was taken to the endoscopy room. He received 100 mg of Demerol and 3 mg of Versed IV. A digital exam showed a large prostate, which he is already seeing a urologist for. No lumps were found. The prostate enlargement was moderate (3+ BPH). The anal canal looked normal, with no strictures, tumors, or ulcers.  

The Olympus CF 20L video scope was inserted through the anus. The anal canal was normal. The sigmoid, descending, splenic, and transverse colon had scattered diverticula. The hepatic flexure, ascending colon, cecum, and ileocecal valve were all normal. The scope was removed and the air was suctioned out.  

The patient was sent home with instructions to eat a high‑fiber, diverticular diet and to have another colonoscopy in three years.
